rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Hammer's lectures were somewhat all over the place and could be confusing, especially if you are unfamiliar with the topic. It was pretty easy to do well in the class if you did all the work and showed up to class and recitations. The work included weekly short writing assignments and a couple papers - not too much.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Todd is amazing. He doesn't believe in tests so the final only counted as 5% of our grade. There are two easy papers and the TA was amazing as well. They both really cared and wanted the best for you. The readings can be tough but Todd explains them all in lecture. Not what you expect but an awesome class nonetheless!

I wish I could take it again! it was definitely unexpected because it was more anthropology than religion, but I still loved his class. He always kept me interested. I took this class as a freshman and it definitely opened my mind. He clearly explained the readings better than any other prof I've had.  Grades depend on TAs though

reli 236 & 140: Todd is absolutely one of my favorite professors at UNC. He's a little out there, but he respects his students and makes difficult concepts more clear. He's very approachable.  If you aren't interested in philosophy/religion you probably won't like the class; but it's easy to succeed if you follow the readings & put in some effort.

He is very invested in the material, although he focuses far more on religious theory than religious practice.  I had him for religion in America.  Has midterm and final papers rather than exams, and uses attendance quizzes.  Doesn't make you get the textbook, loads readings onto Sakai.

Hated this class. Worst class at Carolina because of Todd.  Disliked his spin on INTRODUCTION TO RELIGION AND CULTURE due to his Anthropology background. Very Atheist and publicized his views. Confusing lecturer- not what I expected at all. Wish I would have read reviews first. Even our readings were titled Anth, not Reli. Not a fan. Very unhappy.

Liked the class but it was nothing like I expected. Viewed as more of an anthro category instead of religion and talks about lots of abstract things that you have to be open minded to listen to such as possession by gods or magic.
Really interesting class. This dude knows what he's talking about. Be warned - this class isn't about religious practice, as I expected, but about the thought process behind religion.

Lectures are interesting and Todd is obviously engaged, but he also talks in circles and the content is not AT ALL what anyone comes into the class expecting. Only take this class if you're interested in religion as an anthropological category and in abstract religious ideas

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Ariel veered away from the syllabus to say the least. There was a required reading of at least one novel, usually more per class.  The readings were dense, the videos were boring, he was confusing, not to mention the 12 pg term paper. I would not recommend. He was also HATEFUL if you ever had to miss a class, even if you were sick.
Amazing!!
Very enthusiastic and knowledgeable.

Attendance is mandatory, but you really don't have to pay much attention as long as you look at the study guide before tests. Requires a lot of outside commitment - visiting synagogues and outside lectures. Ariel is funny and the TAs were helpful this semester.

Professor Ariel's class is a lot of work, but not overly hard. His lectures are somewhat unclear, but he tries. My issue is with the TAs. Don't expect to get anything graded back until a month after you submitted it. They are some of the laziest people on the planet.

Professor Ariel is very passionate about the subject. The workload isn't too bad. I learned a lot in RELI 72. If you are looking for an easy first-year seminar, do not take RELI 72. It's not that hard, but it is harder than most first-year seminars. I will say that Prof Ariel tends to interrupt people - even the guest lecturers. Don't take offense.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: The topic of the class was super specific--Animals in Japanese Religion--which made discussion pretty repetitive by the end of the semester. Prof. knows the subject well, but wasn't great at moderating discussion. She was very helpful when working on the final research paper. My enthusiasm for the class really faded over time.

I've thoroughly enjoyed Professor Ambros' class. She integrates various media into her teaching style and we have excellent discussions. We definitely read, but I am grateful for her class because I have a much deeper understanding of how elements of Eastern religions affect Japanese modern culture today, and Eastern Religions in the world.

I don't know if Dr. Ambros has gotten better, or if the other raters just have unreasonable standards.  I like her, the class, and the subject matter.  She is very knowledgeable about Japanese religions.  She even helped me find research articles for a paper that I had to write for another class.  I definitely recommend her class!

Overall, the class was extremely easy.  Dr. Ambros was not a terrible teacher--she was actually quite a fascinating lady--but she was hard to follow in class.  I would recommend taking the class, but I would not recommend buying the textbook on Japanese religion.  You can find all of the information you need online.

Had her for FYS. Participation is a big thing. Otherwise, not too difficult a class. LOTS of reading on weird topics. She helps out with the final paper, so it's not too bad. She's not the most excitable of people though, but she's not a mean person. Never went to office hours, so I don't know if they are helpful.

It was an easy A, and it can fulfill a requirement. The responses were super easy to do, as were the group projects. Class time on the other hand was quite boring, and I had no idea what she was talking about half the time because she was spewing out random Japanese words all the time. And don't bother buying the Sommers book, it's useless.

Class - fascinating, teacher - awful. Lectures - rambling, disjointed, trifling. I stopped going to class b/c it was a waste of time - the tests are wholly based on the reading, and while there's a lot, if you do most of it, you'll be fine. Maybe Ambros is better in other classes, and maybe 183 is better with a different teacher, but I don't know.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Z-man is a revelation all by himself!  Listen, his topics are difficult to explain and it takes someone with an enormous intellect to get these ideas and concepts across.  He invests a lot of energy doing just that.  He is an inspirational professor and he's a pretty groovy guy to boot.

Prof Zlatko is truly an inspirational professor and someone who knows how to keep students engaged. The class had lotssss of reading but it was mostly very interesting. Really nice professor and a challenging, rewarding course

Z-Man is amazing. He keeps you engaged in all of his lectures and is super funny. He really expects you to talk and answer his questions but if you do the reading then it's not hard. I would take him again in a heart beat
Interesting guy and great class.  His attitude towards the subject makes you want to learn more and keeps your attention.  I would take another class with him!

Z-man is the best professor at UNC. He is engaging and funny. You do have to work for his class, but it is well worth it if you are into Religious Studies at all. Even if you are just a Christian and interested in the early centuries, take his "Varieties of Early Christianity." Well worth it.
It has been 4 years since I have graduated, and I still have respect for the man. His class was one of the most memorable for me in my career at Carolina.
No Comments
Zlatko is the man!  How dare you attack his accent!  His accent is frikkin cool!  Great guy, one of the best people I've worked with at UNC.

Zlatko is a great professor, and you cannot expect to learn anything from a great professor without doing some semblence of work.  The Id's could be difficult, but if you've done the reading you should be able to recognize the different tones and writing styles.  Overall, i highly recommend Z.

Zlatko's accent isn't that hard to understand.  There is a lot of reading for this class and you have to identify verses on the midterm and final which is a bit rough.  The class is fun though because Zlatko is really energetic and engaging.

This class is a little hard and Z-man's accent definitely doesn't help matters... But he is funny and likeable which makes class interesting, even though its not always clear.  could be organized better
Z tries really hard, but his accent is hard to understand (not to mention his handwriting). I'd avoid his class, the reading, and the exam ID's.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I took this class because I had an interest in the New Testament, specifically the history of Jesus. Boy, did I learn about the New Testament in this class. This should not be a 100-level course. It was very tough and time consuming for an entry level class - but I learned a lot. Only take Reli 104 if you're seriously curious about it.

This class was one of my favorites thus far at UNC. Don't be fooled it does take A LOT of work and there are papers due each week; however, it was very interesting and I found that it really changed my personal views. The tests are really stressful (the midterm was 5 ID questions... there were over 200 words to study) but they are manageable.

Bart is extremely knowledgeable about his subject and seems to be passionate about teaching it. The course is definitely not easy. Reading and excessive note-taking is necessary. Tests are 150 word IDs on the midterm and IDs mixed with essays on the final. One of the hardest classes I've taken, but an A is possible if you study (a lot).

The comments for this professor are outdated. He is much more difficult than he used to be. Great lecturer, interesting, and very accredited in scholarship of the New Testament. However, his tests are much more than just memorizing terms. I would suggest for Reli majors, but not for people looking for an A in a gen. ed

The class was extremely interesting and entertaining, and the textbook easy to read, but the class required more work than it was worth. One 2-page paper each week, ~40-50 pages of reading each week, a group debate project, & a final exam (10 key term ID's and 2 essays). It's difficult to get an A even if you do all the reading and assignments.

Very interesting professor.  One of UNC's best lecturers and the class is extremely well organized.  The exams consisted of memorizing the key terms in the textbook but if you do that, you are set.  Definitely would recommend

The BEST professor I have ever had at UNC. His classes aren't the easiest, but they're so interesting. Lectures are focused and he makes funny anecdotes here and there. Definitely take a class of his, you won't regret it!
The tests were basically just memorizing all the terms from the text book.... It was an okay class but too much reading for someone who doesn't really care for the subject.

I loved this class.  It was really interesting and I enjoyed going to it.  Ehrman, however, does put his bias into the class and the content he teaches.  He's a great speaker and a nice guy though.  The TAs are awesome!!!  I would suggest this class for people who are comfortable with their religious beliefs.
No Comments

hard class...it's pretty easy to figure out what Bart believes, and chances are, he'll tell you at the end of the semester...exams are ridiculous...you have to basically memorize the entire glossary of your textbook for the final. fairly predictable...great teaching style...but if you choose to share your thoughts, chances are they will be shot dow

Dr. Ehrman was one of my absolute favorite professors in college.  He's entertaining, interesting, open to respectful discussion of different points of view, accessible, and really seems to enjoy teaching. I was not a religion major; I just took the class as an elective and it turned out to be my favorite class all semester.  Highly recommend.

An interesting class, probably the most controversial I've been in. Covers a lot of good material and is an interesting, animated lecturer. Note: this is a history class so don't take it if you don't want to be memorizing tons of information! Final and midterm are difficult, but not too bad if you think about what you need to study.
I LOVED this class.  While it was hard, Ehrman is super interesting and he holds office hours at Armadillo Grill!  He explains the material pretty well and he has a fascinating biography.

one of the best professors i had in college - i actually went to his classes and like it.  and if you take his class - definitely attend the last day that is not mandatory - you'll want to hear his actual opinion instead of just the facts

A life changer if you are lost about things, and engaging if you aren't.  Goes out of his ways to keep personal views private and to respect yours.  Atheists, Agnostics, Buddhists, Jews, Hindus, Muslims, and Evangelical Christians alike could appreciate this man.

Ehrman has been my fave professor, hands down. He has a sarcastic sense of humor that I love and he is engaging and interesting. This is a teacher who makes you actually enjoy going to class. But, as someone else said, if you don't like your religious views challenged at all, don't take this class.
Great instructor.  I thought he went out of his way to keep his personal views private, which i felt was important at a diverse, publicly funded school.  Entertaining, personable instructor.

I truly enjoyed this class with Ehrman.  I feel he is a great lecturer.  He knew the material quite well.  Although, note that he teaches a very liberal view of the Bible, which was quite fascinating even though I personally feel isn't always accurate.
Very difficult, and he teaches to disporve the Bible.  Still, he is an AWESOME lecturer.  Entertaing, funny.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Absolutely loved Jodi!  Her lectures are long but very interesting, and all the material you need for the test and more is described in lecture.  Go to class and take notes and you'll do well!

The only reason I took this class was bc I heard it was an easy A, but they had to CURVE the first exam. I think she got hard after the scandal. Was harder than my Bio 202 class No help at all-- she won't even acknowledge someone who has their hand raised in the front row Doesn't allow technology but talks fast and doesn't post ppts or outlines

Magness is cool, but your grade depends on your TA, and if you need help, you go to them. Magness just lectures and makes the assignments. 3 midterms with 6 identifications and an essay. All given ahead of time. Term paper is tough because the lectures and tests cover different material. NOT AN EASY A. Lectures are mostly about history.

TAs are very inconsistent with grading. There is A LOT of memorization but you're only tested on a couple terms so you still have to study everything. It is clear she is passionate about her subject. To me, she made this boring subject as interesting as it possibly could. GO TO CLASS and take DETAILED notes, including DATESNAMES.

Jodi Magness is the most boring lecturer I've ever had.  She is an elitist who will not tolerate opinions that go against hers.  Her TA's were very inconsistent and they decide your grade as they grade your exams and papers and make your quizzes.  This class was as miserable as it gets.  NEVER TAKE THIS CLASS

A complete waste of a first year seminar- this class was incredibly boring and the daily essays made students feel as though they were imbeciles for not knowing about toilets in 30BC. Do not recommend.

This is a terrible class. Do not be swindled into being convinced that this is an easy A. Worst class I've taken at Carolina, period. Boring and entirely lecture-based, with extreme variations on grades that are entirely dependent on the TA you get. Don't take this class, it's not worth whatever gen ed credits you're trying to get.
This class in NOT an easy A.  DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS if you aren't good at essay writing or history.

Jodi is brilliant. Her class was one of the most interesting classes I have ever taken. Her lectures are well planned and you will learn a lot. She is an expert in her field and talks about her own experiences. She does talk fast, so you have to write down things quickly. Her tests were short ID's and essays, which she gives in advance. Great Prof.

Amazing professor, she does a great job of making all of the lectures interesting. Very experienced in her field of work, so she knows what she's talking about. She doesn't put the notes online so you can't skip lecture without having a friend to get them from. The TAs vary in difficulty but they're fine- I had the hardest one and managed an A-.

This class was supposed to be an easy A.  It wasn't for me.  She is great!  Her lectures were interesting and she gave us the pictures for the ids and the essays before the tests.  Your grade depends on your TA.  I got a B-...

She was probably the best professor I had this semester. She kept the class entertaining. The exams were not to bad, the TAs didnt grade too harshly, and she even offered extra credit opportunities. The hardest part of her class was the 7-8 page term paper due before the thanksgiving break, so if you dont procrastinate on this then youll do fine.

This was a grad/undergrad course, and my major is far outside of the religious studies department. That being said, i found the seminar style class to be interesting and Jodi is very bright and well rehearsed in the subject matter. We did presentations which I did really well on, and then had a 10 pg paper-DONT SCREW UP CITATIONS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
fun

I. Love. Jodi. Magness. She is by far one of the most interesting professors I've had at Carolina. Her test questions come straight from class, so you can't miss it, but it makes them easy (you get the essay ?'s ahead of time). The books basically reiterate class lecture so you don't really have to read. Recitation attendance is mandatory.

Great class, better teacher. She goes incredibly fast but makes ancient religious study very interesting. Tests are ID's and essays given in advance. Normally gives oppertunity for extra credit and a large portion of the final grade is easy recitation attendance.
Great class Great Professor. Incredibly interesting!  Im looking forward to having her again next semester!
As long as you can keep up, this class is great
One of my favorite professors!

Lecture was boring and she packs a lot of info into each lecture. I had to study a bit to keep all the names and dates straight, but I never had to do any of the reading except for what was assigned for recitation. The tests came straight from lecture and with or without the GENEROUS extra credit, I easily got an A!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Lectures were very boring and felt never ending. How harsh the grading is depends on your TA and I learned that all too well this year.  But I didn't read hardly anything or put any effort into the entire year and received a B+ so it is by no means difficult.

Extremely informative. The 14 journals required are easy A's. Essay's not too bad. Ernst is ridiculously knowledgable. He has a blunt turn of phrase that's jarring at first, but it grows on you, and the class's atmosphere is very laid-back and open to debate. I would recommend this to anyone who wants a good overview of Islam.

Ernst is very knowledgeable about this subject. He even wrote one of the books required for the class. He is interested in student's views. However the class was very boring. Only those seriously interested in the subject will probably enjoy it.

He knows everything, but he's pretty boring and kind of an ass in person. The grading is really easy, it's all in two papers, 14 page-long journals and two quizzes. You can skip class and you'll be fine. The reading materials were really interesting to me, and so was recitation, so do those if you're interested in the subject matter.

Incredibly knowledgeable. Very calm and straightforward in lectures, which some could interpret as boring. I enjoyed his humble, quiet sense of humor. You will learn a TON about Islam and early Islamic civilization. Workload was flexible, although it seemed difficult to get more than a B+.

He rambles and spends a good part of every class letting random students talk about whatever they think is interesting. It feels like he skips over anything relevant. You have to write 14 journals, which are easy and you can do without reading but it's annoying. LOTS of reading. Two quizzes (study guides provided). Papers for exams.

Professor Ernst is a brilliant person and his lectures are used to highlight broad concepts. You do have to do the reading though; I got a lot more out of the class when I did it. And there are only a few assignments! If you want reliable background information on Islam, this is the course to take but you do have to have to have interest in it.

I really enjoyed this course. Ernst is one of the most knowledgeable professors i've had. There is a good bit of reading, but they're not terribly boring (I loved Following Muhammad). Like most classes you'll get out what you put in. If you never read or take notes and expect him to essentially write your paper in lecture, i'd skip this one.

I thought Intro to Islamic Civilization was an introductory course.  No.  Half the class dropped it or stopped attending lectures.  DO NOT TAKE IT IF YOU HAVE NO INTEREST IN ISLAMIC EDUCATION; If you do, you'll like his semi-discussion formatted lectures, and (only) 3 assignments (Weekly journals on reading; midterm and final paper).

The worst class I have ever taken!  It was so boring, and he rambled all class long.  He always took questions in lecture, which is usually good, but he was just so boring and rambled so much his answers never made sense.  Excessive reading assignments.  My TA was awful, too, and we had barely any assignments to boost (or earn) grades.
I'm blown away by this man.

i dropped this class because he was extremely boring and had no stucture. lectures were full of him talking very little about the subject and showing pictures from vacation in religious places. when it came time to write papers he expected us to pull things out of thin air since he didnt really teach. you have to teach yourself. 1 TA was mean!
No Comments

Professor Ernst is one of the most interesting and knowledgable people I've ever had the joy of learning from.  He had incredible insights and we had a lot of fun in this class.  The class was small, and we intensively studied Iranian and Islamic culture.  We did a review of travel guides from the 17th century on at his house that was lots of fun!

If you want an honest opinion about Islam or Muslims this is your class. Ernsts book Following Muhammad would recommend to anyone. He teaches this class like a grad level course and the learning is on you. I thought the TA's graded the papers fairly and I scored poorly on one. Just put in the time.

Ernst is incredibly boring and his lectures are very unorganized. I couldn't really tell what the concepts were that he was trying to emphasize. The 4 essays we wrote, which are practically the only grades, were graded way too strictly. I don't know too much more now that I did before about Islam.

Awful. You must love Islamic history to enjoy this. Don't bother reading because he summarizes in class. Essay for midterm and final. Graded harder than english papers, which is insane because we know nothing about Islam (why else are we taking this class?). Captain Boring. Could be a lot better!
